reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Increasing the Capacity of Russian nature Reserves and parks to conserve Imperiled Habitats and Species

description.narrative: Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. Programs in this element should be integrated with the Agriculture Area under Economic Growth and Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Area under the Peace and Security Category, when applicable and appropriate.

This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes This project provides funding for scientific field work within the Wrangel Island Federal Biosphere Reserve in Russia specifically pertaining to the population of snow geese shared with the United States. Additionally, the proposal will fund a small grants competition for Russian nature reserves and parks. USFWS and the recipient will work collaboratively on advertising the grants competition to Russia’s nature reserves and parks, receiving and translating proposals. The recipient will organize one proposal review panel in Russia, and USFWS will organize one review panel in the United States. Funding decisions will be made jointly between USFWS and ANO Ekosentr Zapovedniki, and USFWS will have final approval for all final funding decisions. USFWS and ANO Ekosentr Zapovedniki will communicate with the sub-grantees and collaboratively monitor technical and administrative performance. Sub-grants funded by this award will improve the protected areas’ law enforcement, visitor center services, reserve management, and biodiversity conservation through training courses, the purchase of patrolling equipment, and the increased presence of law enforcement officers. Species to benefit include the critically endangered saiga antelope, Amur tiger, polar bear, walrus, Far Eastern leopard, snow goose, and Asiatic black bear..

participating-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

participating-org.usg:office-name: Fish and Wildlife Service/Office of International Affairs

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: U.S. assistance programs are designed to promote Russia’s role as a stable, democratic, and reliable partner in addressing crucial global issues, to support U.S.-Russian cooperation in areas of common interest, to advance priorities outlined by the Bilateral Presidential Commission (BPC) Working Groups, and to develop partnerships that leverage Russia’s considerable resources in solving domestic and international problems. At the same time, the United States will support Russian organizations that encourage the adoption of policies and practices that promote democratic norms on issues such as human rights, civil society, and the rule of law. Programs under the Peace and Security objective will complement broader U.S. Government efforts under the Cooperative Threat Reduction Program to enhance nuclear cooperation and reduce the threat of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD). Secretary Clinton noted that the coming years will be crucial for Russian democracy, as Russians from all walks of life make their voices heard and express their hopes for the future. Programs under the Governing Justly and Democratically objective will promote U.S. interests in a strong, politically vibrant, open, democratic Russia, as well as deepening the U.S.-Russian partnership. Resources will also help fight the transnational threats of epidemic disease, such as multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). (Source: Congressional Budget Justification FY 2013)
